subject: Use the 'ironic' queue for the gate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-25 18:55:34.000000000', 'files': ['zuul.d/project.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/efb93bf30fbac0dd18a52a3334c63ff479c2f35d', 'message': "Use the 'ironic' queue for the gate

When doing the 'gate' build have the ironic-inspector jobs be part of
the 'ironic' queue. More information on this is in [1]. The benefit of
this is that we are only impacted by ironic projects if we do this and
openstack/ironic is also using the 'ironic' queue.

From [1]:
Pipelines which use the dependent pipeline manager maintain separate
queues for groups of projects. When Zuul serializes a set of changes
which represent future potential project states, it must know about
all of the projects within Zuul which may have an effect on the
outcome of the jobs it runs. If project A uses project B as a library,
then Zuul must be told about that relationship so that it knows to
serialize changes to A and B together, so that it does not merge a
change to B while it is testing a change to A.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/infra/zuul/feature/zuulv3/user/config.html

Change-Id: I735dc13c288bc16c9d4ea6bc0a63ca24a70b3272
"}]
commit_message:
Use the 'ironic' queue for the gate

When doing the 'gate' build have the ironic-inspector jobs be part of
the 'ironic' queue. More information on this is in [1]. The benefit of
this is that we are only impacted by ironic projects if we do this and
openstack/ironic is also using the 'ironic' queue.

From [1]:
Pipelines which use the dependent pipeline manager maintain separate
queues for groups of projects. When Zuul serializes a set of changes
which represent future potential project states, it must know about
all of the projects within Zuul which may have an effect on the
outcome of the jobs it runs. If project A uses project B as a library,
then Zuul must be told about that relationship so that it knows to
serialize changes to A and B together, so that it does not merge a
change to B while it is testing a change to A.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/infra/zuul/feature/zuulv3/user/config.html

Change-Id: I735dc13c288bc16c9d4ea6bc0a63ca24a70b3272

commit_message:
Remove default_bind_mount_logs from config changes.

Changing the value for default_bind_mount_logs on upgrade will make all
container restart. It only make sense to add this to the config when:
- you upgrade to the release that changes the default behavior
    - this is to keep the old default.
- The setting is not set in the configuration.
    - If the config is present, you don't want to change it.

Change-Id: I37217352357dee8c844d3b20d28075f7e4ef1223
Related-Bug: #1745212
(cherry picked from commit 7cd9fec86f11a294b67b8ae990141cdb7a97fdfe)

commit_message:
Remove Simple Crypto plugin production warning

Folks are using this for production, and in reality, even though the
plugin is not ideal, one can take measures to secure this backend enough
that it will be fine for most use-cases. Taking this into account, I'm
removing this warning that's putting users/deployers off.

Change-Id: I35ba3f78da6c77e2812fc7ec259cf149ab825caa

commit_message:
Prepare Team Directories

Setup directories for candidates to submit to
for the upcoming Rocky PTL election. Security is
not being included because it is becoming a SIG at
the end of this release.

Change-Id: I6ec5274287af346ac5d39121f1ab3f1aff600de3

commit_message:
Only run openstack-tox-functional on nova stable branches

Change Ia684786d1622da7af31aa4479fc883a7c65848ff creates a
nova-specific tox functional job in the nova repo. That
is merged on master but not stable branches yet.

This change makes the openstack-tox-functional job only run
on stable branches since on master we run nova-tox-functional.

Since the functional py35 job was only running on master, it's
simply removed since nova-tox-functional-py35 (defined in-repo)
replaces it.

A follow up change will remove openstack-tox-functional altogether.

Change-Id: Ibdd11c4d461b8434bf90df70864c4fcdbbc2304e

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-03 16:35:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/52f7d72f457ec76ad0544141165f8f97f00866f3', 'message': 'Add a return code check to the osa wrapper

the after run report will show something "failed" even when the run
succeeds. This creates a poor user experience when looking at the
playbook runs, especially as a new user. This change adds a simple
return code check when the openstack-ansible wrapper is used and reports
if the run succeeds or is a failure based on the RC. This should help
users understand when something actually fails, at a glance.

commit_message:
Add a return code check to the osa wrapper

Due to our use of block/rescue pattern in some of the playbooks/roles
the after run report will show something "failed" even when the run
succeeds. This creates a poor user experience when looking at the
playbook runs, especially as a new user. This change adds a simple
return code check when the openstack-ansible wrapper is used and reports
if the run succeeds or is a failure based on the RC. This should help
users understand when something actually fails, at a glance.

> NOTE: This change should no longer be needed as soon as we're able
  to move to ansible 2.5 which improves the UX when the block/rescue
  pattern is used.

With this change a user will see an "EXIT NOTICE" which is reported in a
way that resembles how ansible reports information on a playbook run
which should be simple to see and understand in almost all cases.

Change-Id: Ic54a7524c09a170e20830c5f8d2c2a0658159ed0
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: tasks: lxc_post_install: Handle missing init.scope scope

commit_message:
tasks: lxc_post_install: Handle missing init.scope scope

The init.scope was added in systemd-v226 and support for the pid
controller was added in systemd-v227. However, stable distributions may
be on older systemd version so we need to check whether the scope exists
before we try to adjust the maximum number of processes for that scope.

Change-Id: Ic38e17d110e7a72770286c2faf571ba03bde7f32
Link: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/efdb02375beb0a940c3320865572913780b4d7de
Link: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/03a7b521e3ffb7f5d153d90480ba5d4bc29d1e8f
Closes-Bug: #1743382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts refs/changes/75/533675/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Check that the init.scope support the pid controller stat: path: "/sys/fs/cgroup/pids/init.scope/pids.max" register: _init_scope_pid tags: - lxc-config when: _init_scope_pid.stat.exists

were templates were copied from tripleo-ci in

commit_message:
Use relative path in ipv6 nic configs

The path to run-os-net-config.sh in these nic config templates for ci
should be relative, not absolute. The absolute path does not honor a
different directory specified via --templates, and it also fails the
overcloud deploy entirely b/c the absolute path does not exist in the
plan in swift.

Change-Id: I85ac081571965f42beef4bd283db985b9a03078f
(cherry picked from commit c74318381c91751e0f43f1b99f26011cecafe440)

commit_message:
Create compute pre_upgrade script for oooq.

In TripleO CI the hostname doesn't
have an indicator of the role the node
takes. For that reason, it's necessary
to modify the condition that identifies
the overcloud node as a compute one.

Change-Id: Ie544882cb262ba8aa578cf648fc2a9a8fedc47fc

commit_message:
Set restrictive file permissions on Ceph keyrings for non-containerized deployment

Pass mode parameter 0640 and user and group ownership to puppet-ceph for
Ceph openstack client keyrings during non-containerized deployment.

Author:    Keith Schincke <kschinck@redhat.com>
Co-Author:    John Fulton <fulton@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ie968e6abc6969c37be0a62ac45999093120673d4
Depends-On: Ie968e6abc6969c37be0a62ac45999093120673d4
Partial-Bug: #1720787
(cherry picked from commit bdf1ade1b9de994c3098fb17cca6dd64b3d14cd5)

commit_message:
Replace curly quotes with straight quotes

Curly quotes usually input from Chinese input method.
When read from english context, it makes some confusion.

Change-Id: Iac767651ec7afd1ef8a656c96a5735ed00310319

subject: Start using ipv6 nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-29 15:38:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/66a605dc1c14c52da9a357407a4fdccf76cadc73', 'message': "Start using ipv6 nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create ipv6 multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about

commit_message:
Start using ipv6 nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create ipv6 multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about
backwards-compatibility and breaking users on upgrade.

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline
with the other heat environments we have moved out of the CI repo.
It also allows an end user to start from a configuration that we
have actually CI'd.

Change-Id: Iba56667e11510a1cc2470a7dfdc6bc0158878010
(cherry picked from commit 3fc4da76ab0970b6cc2a2648d1908158fa0fcc02)
(cherry picked from commit 7232568a267622a15eeef663978e0650a8ea1f85)

commit_message:
Start using nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about
backwards-compatibility and breaking users on upgrade.

We may want to also consider a massive cleanup of the existing
network dir with a proper deprecation period, but that is an
exercise left for later.

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline
with the other heat environments we have moved out of the CI repo.
It also allows an end user to start from a configuration that we
have actually CI'd (though there are some settings like MTU that
are not actually good for a real deployment).

Change-Id: I9fd8b8bbcf18d26b1e05d33e2598c0d146814aff
(cherry picked from commit 10b749c043700369d4ea89d5a238173c4dde1d7e)
(cherry picked from commit f09e6acefd93b800e275131a3712f905bf4e3aa5)

commit_message:
Remove use of unsupported TEMPEST_SERVICES variable

TEMPEST_SERVICES global variable is not supported
by devstack since long back.
- I380dd20e5ed716a0bdf92aa02c3730359b8136e4
- I9c24705e494689f09a885eb0a640efd50db33fcf

Service availability of tempest known services will be
set by devstack with local check.
- I02be777bf93143d946ccbb8e9eff637bfd1928d4

This commit removes the unused TEMPEST_SERVICES setting
Related-Bug: #1743688

Change-Id: I753390dd237dd5091025d7fea8f6153fc5362a0f

commit_message:
Set glance images dir owners each time

After a deployment of Queens, glance's images directory comes up with
ownership of `root:root` when it should be `glance:glance`. This
prevents an end user from uploading an image.

This patch removes the stat check of the images directory and always
ensures the directory is created. If the directory already exists,
the create task will ensure that the directory has its ownership
set appropriately.

Closes-Bug: 1742951
Change-Id: I286d6fbdfdec932ea031916f5460710a23d68374

commit_message:
placement: using the dict format for the allocation in claim_resources

In the placement API version 1.12, the dict format is consistent format in
the APIs `PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid}`, `GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid}`
and `GET /allocation_candidates`. This patch switches to this consistent
format in the claim_resources method.

There is one upgrade scene which needs to be care. Since we send alternative
hosts to the compute node as Selection object. The Selection object includes
the json dict of allocation object. That means if a try of instance building
happened in the middle of upgrade, the old format allocation json dict will
send back to the new version cell conductor. So the claim_resources method
still needs to support old version allocation json format.

Change-Id: I4314ade528c9cb69bbf6c55d31566e1e188fef09

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== Support Filter Alarms By Timestamp ================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/aodh/+spec/place-holder https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-aodhclient/+spec/place-holder Problem description =================== Event alarm has been supported by Aodh, to improve the performance, it uses ttl to cache alarms. However, ttl should not be very large, at least should large than 1 minute comparing to threshold alarm, because event alarm aims to provide real time alarming service. Meanwhile, if ttl is small, then we will retrieve all enabled event alarms when ttl exipres. In a middle or large scale deployment, it is a burden for Aodh API and decrease the response time for event alarm. Proposed change =============== Here I proposal a change that enable us to retrieve alarms filtered by their last update time, named "timstamp", so event evaluator can only get alarms from last ttl expire time. To allow such functionality, here are what we need to do: * update timestamp when we call , currently we only update the state_timestamp field, it is wrong actually * provide storage level support for such feature * provide API level support for such feature * provide CLI level support for such feature Alternatives ------------ Let event evaluator suffer. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- New parameter provided, but user can ignore it if they don't interest. Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- Yes, aodh-listener and aodh-api will be happy. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None, or they have more code to maintain? Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <zqfan> Other contributors: <None> Ongoing maintainer: <zqfan> Work Items ---------- See the above section. Future lifecycle ================ More attribute can be filtered, provide more sensitive API user experience. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit test and API test will be provide along with code. Documentation Impact ==================== Yes, we need to update our document for such feature. References ========== None

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Support Alarm Metering Data =========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/place-holder https://blueprints.launchpad.net/aodh/+spec/place-holder Problem description =================== As a cloud vendor, I want to telemetring alarm resources, so I can billing for such resources, but now, Ceilometer doesn't collect such metering data, the only way we have is providing a very limited quota to every project. This situation needs to be improved. Proposed change =============== For each polling cycle, ceilometer polling agent will call Aodh API to get alarms usage for each project, then record as samples to back end, so billing service can retrieve that data and charge on it. Aodh will provide an API: /v2/alarms/usage?project_id=<PROJECT_ID> If caller is non admin, then it will only return its own usage data. If caller is admin and no project_id is specified, then will return a list of all projects, each element is an usage data for a project. If caller is admin and project_id is specified, only that project's usage data will be returned. the response is like this: [ { 'total': 999, 'alarm': 1, 'ok': 998, 'insufficient_data': 0, 'project_id': '113670876ce64d69bc9b8288ffc7d7f5' } ] Group by user_id will not be supported, we charge on project, not on individual user. When user create an alarm, update it or delete it, aodh-api will send a notification to AMQP, to notify Ceilometer that there is an event occurs. aodh-evaluator and aodh-listener will not send a notification to AMQP for such case, because we only want to audit user operations. The notification event_type will be: * alarm.create.end (no start because we only write database) * alarm.update.end (ditto) * alarm.delete.end (ditto) the payload will be consistent to the alarm API model, such as: { "alarm_actions": [], "alarm_id": "aa0541eb-6384-4579-b128-6e598533913b", "description": "Alarm when * event occurred.", # not usefull "enabled": true, "rule": { "event_type": "*", "query": [] }, "id": "aa0541eb-6384-4579-b128-6e598533913b", # oh no, the debt "insufficient_data_actions": [], "name": "I wish you have a happy life", "ok_actions": [], "project_id": "74a0f0d8734d46a18773139c0c331e5e", "repeat_actions": False, "severity": "low", "state": "insufficient data", "state_timestamp": "2016-04-23T05:45:45.724697", "time_constraints": [], "timestamp": "2016-04-25T12:26:50.391207", "type": "event", "user_id": "c417eb1ad2534df483e9065c03ab8da8" } Ceilometer can dicide what to do for such notification, store it to event backend and allow elasticsearch do something usefull, or drop it, whatever. The notification can be shutdown by configuration, just like other services do. Alternatives ------------ Lie down there and wait for complaint. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Aodh will have a new API /v2/alarms/usage?project_id=<ID> Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <zqfan> Other contributors: <None> Ongoing maintainer: <zqfan> Work Items ---------- * Aodh provide the usage API * Aodh send notification when API does CUD on alarm * Ceilometer pollster for alarm count * Ceilometer event for alarm notification Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * unit test for source code * gabbi test for Aodh new API Documentation Impact ==================== Will along with the code. References ========== None

commit_message:
Extend the validation for generic pollster

In this blueprint, the following tasks have been done.

a. The mechanism to implement the meter definition validator
b. The design SNMP validator

Most of the work have done in the change set:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/262660/

During the review, llu and I have agreement on implementing a
mechanism for the new validator can be added in the future and the
validator can be loaded dynamicly during loading the defferent
meter definition.

Based on the above reason, I write down this design in order to
add the new validator in the future.

Change-Id: Idd2fa196ca71bcb42609b113b730c7a5a28726a0
blueprint: extend-validation-for-generic-pollster
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/19/278419/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Add the validation for generic pollster ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/extend-validation-for-generic-pollster Now when the generic pollster loads the specified meter definition file, it can not validate whether the meter definition is valid. It leads the pollster fails when it's invoked and throws the exceptions that can not loacte the problem clearly. The generic pollster should validate the specified meter definition when loading them and filter the invalid meter definition. And the error messages should be print in the log file to help the user to identify the problems. Based on the generic pollster design, the kink of the inspector invoked by the generic pollster is agnostic. So is the validator invokded by the generic pollster. In this blueprint, the following works are described. a. The mechanism will be introduced that the speifiled validator is invoked based on the kind of the meter definition during loading the meter definition file. b. The design of the validator for SNMP. Problem description =================== Now the generic pollster does not validate the detailed specified meter definition. It only validates the general definition. If the user defines the wrong meter in the file, the generic pollster will not notify the user and filter the wrong meter definition. The inspector will be invoked by the generic pollster with the wrong meter definition. It will lead the pollster fails and the exceptions are thrown. And the error message in the log file can not identify the problem clearly. The bug that the invalid snmp meter definition leads the pollster to fail has been reported in the launchpad.[1] The generic pollster should validate the detailed specified meter definition during loading the meter file and filter the wrong definition. The detailed error info should be reported in the error log. Assist the user to identify the root cause. Proposed change =============== i. The mechanism that the speifiled validator is invoked based on the kind of the meter definition during loading the meter definition file. a. A base class 'InspectorMeterDefinition' will be defined in the base.py and one abstract method 'validate_definition' will be defined in it. All the class used to validate the meter definition should inherit from it and implement the method 'validate_definition'. b. The new namespace 'ceilometer.hardware.validators' will be added. And the method 'get_validator' will be defined in the __init__.py to load the specified validator driver based on the type of the meter definition. c. All the new validator drivers should be added in the namespace 'ceilometer. hardware.validators' in the setup.cfg. d. Add the validator in the generic pollster during loading the meter definition. ii. The design of the validator for SNMP. a. The class 'SNMPMeterDefinition' inherit from the base 'InspectorMeterDefinition' is implement. b. The method 'get_validator' is implement with the following rules according to RFC 2578[2]: 1. The matching_type field must be set as non-null value. 2. The oid field must be set as non-null value. 3. The oid should be sperated by '.'. 4. The first sub-identifier should be 1, 2. 5. The oid should contain two sub-identifiers at least. 6. The value of each sub-identifier should be non-negative number, between 0 and 4294967295. 7. The sub-identifier 0 should be the last one in the OID object instance. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- jizilian Primary assignee: jizilian Other contributors: Ongoing maintainer: Work Items ---------- i. Implement the mechanism that the speifiled validator is invoked based on the kind of the meter definition during loading the meter definition file. ii. Implement the validator for SNMP. Future lifecycle ================ Ongoing maintenance will be handled by the Ceilometer team, myself included. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit and integration Tests will be added to cover the tests. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1]https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1503265 [2]http://www.rfc-base.org/txt/rfc-2578.txt

commit_message:
This BP supports alarm type for event-alarm

Provides infrastructure for different types of event-alarm, so that
adding new alarm type(like comb and event-timeout) in future is easy.

blueprint alarm-type-for-event-alarm

Change-Id: I0ce9c1823aed797e1d946d76aea2a7123c3f267b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/63/258163/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================== Alarm Type for Event Alarm ========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/aodh/+spec/alarm-type-for-event-alarm This BP adds alarm-type infrastructure for event-alarm, so developer can easily add new alarm-type, like comb event-alarm. Problem description =================== Currently event-alarm only supports one basic alarm-type: get alarmed when desired event comes. In future, we need add more alarm-types for different evaluation, like comb event-alarm or event-timeout-alarm. All of them are triggered by event, but should be alarmed in different way: comb event-alarm should be fired if each sub-alarm fired, while event-timeout-alarm be fired when desired event doesn't come for a long time. Adding all the logic in current basic event-alarm is complicated, and bug-prone. Proposed change =============== Make EventAlarmEvaluator one abstract class, and all evaluators for different alarm type, like event, event-comb, and event-timeout, should derive from it. Each subclass should override some abstruct function, like _evaluate_alarm, to reflect its own evaluation behavior. Each subclass should provide unique alarm type, like 'event_comb', so that _get_project_alarms could return the alarms of this type evaluator only. Each event-alarm evaluator should be a plugin loaded by stevedore in setup.cfg with entry named "aodh.event.evaluator". This BP is just refactoring of current code, which build the infrastructure to facilitate adding new alarm type in future. After receiving any events on bus, EventAlarmEndpoint iterates a list of evaluators, each for one event-alarm type, instead of just one evaluator as current. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- This BP itself is code refactoring, thus no performance impact. New alarm type in future could introduce a little bit performance drop, as events should go through each evaluator for evaluation. Other deployer impact --------------------- This BP need change setup.cfg to load the basic event-alarm evaluator. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: edwin-zhai Work Items ---------- * Make EventAlarmEvaluator abstract class by setting _evaluate_alarm as abstractmethod. * New EventAlarmBasicEvaluator derive from EventAlarmEvaluator with 'type' as 'event-basic', and reuse current _evaluatoe_alarm implementation. Add "aodh.event.evaluator" entry in setup.cfg, and put EventAlarmBasicEvaluator in it. * EventAlarmEvaluationService loads plugins in "aodh.event.evaluator" entry when init, and iterates all evaluatros when events come. Future lifecycle ================ To be maintained by edwin-zhai for bug fixing and enhancement. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= This BP is just code refactoring, so current function tests already cover it. Some unit test needed for new code. No need of tempest cases. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== Blueprint Timeout mechanism for Event Alarm Evaluator, which adds new alarm type to track critical event missing. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/timeout-event-alarm-evaluator

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/60/408060/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============ Custom Alarm ============ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/aodh/+spec/custom-alarm This blueprint proposes to add a new alarm type allowing for alarm creation and triggering from other OpenStack projects. Custom alarms will include metadata fields and will post immediate alarm notifications upon state change, but do not require evaluation as these are triggered externally. Problem description =================== As Aodh is the OpenStack alarm engine, it should provide a more flexible and customizable approach for alarm triggering by external projects. Vitrage for example, produces insights that may result in new alarms. Existing alarm types in Aodh require evaluation, and do not provide a means to create on-the-fly an alarm definition and trigger it while notifying users. Furthermore, existing alarms do not contain a field where metadata about the new alarm can be preserved. Proposed change =============== The proposal is to add a new alarm type "custom", which does not require evaluation. Triggering can be done by the set_state api, or by providing "state" with alarm-create and alarm-update APIs. The new alarm type will have a metadata field - This enables users / other projects to create and raise an alarm on-the-fly and preserve information of the alarm origin. The main difference of this alarm compared to existing Aodh alarms is in the lack of evaluation. Alternatives ------------ At the moment Vitrage, which exports it's alarms to Aodh, uses an Event Alarm to create the alarm in Aodh, storing the data in the query field. This solution has a few limitations: 1. Event alarm requires evaluation which takes precious time. We want the alarm to be raised instantly (on-the-fly). 2. For external triggering, there is no alternative. External alarms from Zabbix\Nagios cannot be created or managed in Aodh. 3. Storing the data in the query field in the event alarm is an ugly workaround that uses the query field not for it's designated purpose. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Alarm API will be extended as follows; * Add "custom" type into alarm type list * Add "metadata" to "alarm" which is a key value dictionary Sample data of custom type alarm:: { "alarm_id": 96aebe78-0caf-4bb3-b246-35b738ba7f9c, "description": "Vitrage alarm raised on an instance - connectivity problem", "enabled": true, "name": "ConnectivityDegraded", "metadata": { "alarm_origin": "vitrage.evaluator", "vitrage_id" : "acbdfbd8b494863567c96c887c216949", "affected_resource_id" : "6c887c216949c5d8b49acbdfb4863567", "affected_resource_type" : "nova.instance" }, "project_id": "c96c887c216949acbdfbd8b494863567", "repeat_actions": false, "severity": "moderate", "state": "alarm", "state_timestamp": "2016-04-03T17:49:38.406845", "timestamp": "2016-04-03T17:49:38.406839", "type": "custom", "user_id": "c96c887c216949acbdfbd8b494863567" } Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: alexey_weyl <alexey.weyl@nokia.com> Other contributors: idan-hefetz <idan.hefetz@nokia.com> Ongoing maintainer: None Work Items ---------- None Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= New unit/scenario tests are required for this change. Documentation Impact ==================== * Administrator Guide and Installation Guide in OpenStack Manuals should be updated to describe new alarm type as well as all deployer impacts. References ========== [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Vitrage

commit_message:
Collect neutron security group meters for instance ports

Ceilometer Currently has no support for metering the drop bytes/pkts
for instance ports associated with security group. By default the
security group is enabled for every instance port. The security group
meters are important for security analysis.

This spec is to collect send/receive/drop meters, the meters can be
used for security analysis or alarming.

Co-Authored-By: jizilian(jizilian@cn.ibm.com)
Co-Authored-By: lulk(lulk@cn.ibm.com)
blueprint: support-to-collect-neutron-port-meters
Change-Id: I765eb4eb1849519efa3db3534a35cfbd13993e0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/75/273475/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support collect neutron port meters ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/support-to-collect-neutron-port-meters Neutron has applied security group on ports to control the network traffic of instance[1]. Access to instances is controlled by security groups which are a collection of inbound (ingress) and outbound (egress) rules. The rules are about which sources, protocols and ports a server can send/receive traffic from. No traffic can be received by a server unless a security group rule explicitly allows it if security group is enabled by default. By default the security group service is enabled and default rule will be applied on neutron port. The network traffic statistics, including send/receive/drop statistics, are recorded on host iptables. Those data can be used for billing and security analysis. The goal of this blueprint is to collect the meters of port when neutron security group is enabled by default. Problem description =================== Ceilometer Currently has no support for metering the statistics of neutron port when security group is enabled. By default the neutron security group is enabled on port and default rules will be applied on every port. Users would use neutron security group rules to control the network traffic on instance. There are two common scenarios [1]: 1. Users create a neutron port and associate security group with the port, repeat if it has multiple vNICs, then launch a VM passing the port-id and finally got the VM where security group rules are applied. 2. Users request Nova to launch an instance specifying security groups associated. Nova will create neutron port and associate security group with the ports then launch the instance for users. We can support collecting the network statistics of neutron port in order to know the network traffic(send/receive/drop) for an instance. The collected statistics can be used for billing, analysis, alarming, or other projects/systems. Proposed change =============== The proposal try to solve the problem described above with changes: * We can only get the statistics only when the security group is enabled on port. In order to collect the statistics of neutron port, first we need to make sure the security group is enabled. Use neutron client to get all ports, then use the flag of “port_security_enabled” or the length of security groups field in every port details to determine if it is enabled. If disabled, we don’t poll the metrics of this port. * As we collect port metrics on compute node, we will use polling agent. A new namespace will be created. Define it as “network.sg.port”, each meters above will run under this namespace as a pollster. The measurements needed for metering neutron port are list below: Name Type Unit Origin network.services.sg.port.accept_rx_byte g type p network.services.sg.port.accept_tx_byte g type p network.services.sg.port.accept_rx_packet g packet p network.services.sg.port.accept_tx_packet g packet p network.services.sg.port.drop_rx_byte g type p network.services.sg.port.drop_tx_byte g type p network.services.sg.port.drop_rx_packet g packet p network.services.sg.port.drop_tx_packet g packet p Note: g : gauge d : delta p : pollster n : notification * In order to get accurate values of meters above, we use iptables command on compute node. Use "iptables -vnL" command, all the details will be shown in the filter table on compute node. The filter table include INPUT, OUTPUT, FORWARD chains. The neutron security group will work on the FORWARD chain. To get network.services.sg.port.accept_rx_*, and network.services.sg.port.accept_tx_* values, 1. Look up the FORWARD chain. The traffic will be record on "neutron-openvswi-sg-chain". 2. Look up the "neutron-openvswi-sg-chain" chain. Assume we have a port and its id is 47f860ec-7484-40be-87e3-f3fc4ed3bd3e, in the chain there will be "neutron-openvswi-i47f860ec-7" and "neutron-openvswi-o47f860ec-7" two rules. The two rules aims to record the incoming and outgoing traffic of the port, the two rules are named with the first ten characters of port id. Before partial id, "i" and "o" represents incoming and outgoing traffic. 3. Look up "neutron-openvswi-o47f860ec-7", RETURN means packets/bytes are accepted. If it has other rules, look up into it and get the values of RETURN. Aggregate all the RETURN values together will get "port.accept.rx" value. Aggregate all the DROP values together will get “port.drop.rx” value. 4. Look up "neutron-openvswi-i47f860ec-7", RETURN means packets/bytes are accepted. If it has other rules, look up into it and get the values of RETURN. Aggregate all the RETURN values together will get "port.accept.tx" value. Aggregate all the DROP values together will get “port.drop.rx” value. We have to notice that the INPUT chain, will also have the "neutron-openvswi-i47f860ec-7" and "neutron-openvswi-o47f860ec-7" rules. These means the traffic which its destination IP is host IP but not the VM IP will also get in to the chain. So the two rules actually contain the broadcast traffic like DHCP and the traffic which destination IP is VM IP. Alternatives ------------ Currently Ceilometer supports the network meters of instances [3]. It gets the statistics from hypervisor. Meter name Type Unit Resource network.incoming.bytes.rate Gauge B/s interface ID network.outgoing.bytes.rate Gauge B/s interface ID network.incoming.packets.rate Gauge packet/s interface ID network.outgoing.packets.rate Gauge packet/s interface ID … But those meters are different from the meters proposed. Actually the network statistics from looking up hypervisor already have been filtered by security group [2]. The real network traffic should be watched from neutron port where the neutron security groups are defined through iptables. Those statistics are useful for billing or security analysis. We can let the two ways of collecting network statistics co-exist. From nova perspective, to get the overview of instance condition, we can poll the network statistics via hypervisor. From neutron or billing perspective, we get the network statistics from neutron port. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- ljxiash jizilian lulk Primary assignee: ljxiash Other contributors: jizilian lulk Ongoing maintainer: ljxiash jizilian lulk Work Items ---------- A. Implement the pollsters for neutron port B. Add the related doc C. Unit test D. Function test Future lifecycle ================ Ongoing maintenance will be handled by the Ceilometer team, myself included. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit and function test need to be covered. Documentation Impact ==================== Need to update the related doc. References ========== [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/SecurityGroups [2] http://pinrojas.com/2014/07/29/theres-real-magic-behind-openstack-neutron/ [3] http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/telemetry-measurements.html

commit_message:
Render policy in documentation

This is the final bit to implementing the policy goal for Panko.
This just ensures the policies registered in code are actually
rendered in documentation and up-to-date.

Change-Id: I5c97263b84695c0a83dc82782d2f8861dca8ced5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/panko refs/changes/47/523447/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =================== Panko Sample Policy =================== The following is a sample panko policy file that has been auto-generated from default policy values in code. If you're using the default policies, then the maintenance of this file is not necessary, and it should not be copied into a deployment. Doing so will result in duplicate policy definitions. It is here to help explain which policy operations protect specific panko APIs, but it is not suggested to copy and paste into a deployment unless you're planning on providing a different policy for an operation that is not the default. The sample policy file can also be viewed in `file form <_static/panko.policy.yaml.sample>`_. .. literalinclude:: _static/panko.policy.yaml.sample

commit_message:
devstack: update local.conf.example to use lib/neutron

now networking-odl/devstack is using lib/neutron instead of
lib/neutron-legacy. So update local.conf.example to adapt it.

Change-Id: Ia28df4e0fae735d9ab365e5c64c75fb88af6fe90
Closes-Bug: #1740007

commit_message:
Gate/Doc: Move neutron config to gate scripts

This PS moves the neutron configuration to the gate scripts, rather
than mixing it between set and values commands, which was hard to
follow.

Change-Id: I94035d2af15efbe961366ae0427b39721b7aff78

commit_message:
Helm-Test: remove user and tenant creation from test context

This PS removes the user managemnt from the rally driven helm tests
which allows LDAP and other read only sources being used to validate
service functionality, in addition to reducing false -ve results in
the Zuul gates.

Change-Id: I1cc0e99bf74d578648b3cd40eaf60c1804044d88

commit_message:
LOG.warning on unplug_vifs InstanceNotFound

This changes the LOG level from exception to warning on an
InstanceNotFound exception during unplug_vifs. Since no action is being
taken on this exception the warning level is more appropriate.

Change-Id: I8778e3aa80089445fb51431db9a2feeb9db0399b

commit_message:
use . instead of source.

Code conventions: Use “.” to source script files
When you have to source a script file, for example ,
a credentials file to gain access to user-only or
 admin-only CLI commands, use . instead of source.
See more:
http://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/writing-style/code-conventions

Change-Id: Icaf20628e7b7480ee4ca4c85f9c5a3802b817070

commit_message:
Transformers for events pipeline

blueprint events-pipeline-transformers

Change-Id: Ie7426dab4f32b184f7abd532234bd5bbd03f3ffb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/67/162167/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== Transformers for Event Pipeline =============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/events-pipeline-transformers Problem description =================== Recently Events started to store via pipeline, that gives an opportunity not only to store raw Events, but also use transformers for them. So new transformers specialized for events are now required. Proposed change =============== Like samples, we can use transformers for events. In new transformers it is proposed to use 'bracketing' approach, that means that we will wait while start and end Event will arise for certain occurrence. Even more, waiting end Event could be limited by timeout parameter that should be add to the transformer. The proposed schema of 'bracketer' transformer is:: transformers: - name: bracketer start: - event_type: <event_type> - conditions: - <trait>:<value> end: - event_type: <event_type> - conditions: - <trait>:<value> timeout: <time in minutes> #max time that transformer waits for end Event Within this spec events transformers will be implements they could be used to make event statistic more full and informational. For example, with help of bracketing transformer we will have an opportunity to store additional events of successfully and unsuccessfully spawned vms in certain period of time with and get that data with a simple request. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Pipeline impact --------------- This spec propose additional transformers that could be used in event_pipeline.yaml Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- This will add an opportunity to use more full and informational events statistic. Other deployer impact --------------------- Optional: configuration options for event_pipeline.yaml Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ityaptin Ongoing maintainer: idegtiarov Work Items ---------- - create bracketer transformer Future lifecycle ================ Implement events statistics Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= - extend event_pipeline testing to include event_transformers Documentation Impact ==================== - rewrite event_pipeline notes to include new event transformers References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/notification-pipeline

Change-Id: I2a54a33108b3453c87c0337aea33b0eb2b8789b2
'}]
commit_message:
Add snmp alarm notifier

Change-Id: I2a54a33108b3453c87c0337aea33b0eb2b8789b2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/16/184816/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== SNMP Notifier Spec ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/snmp-alarm-notifier Ceilometer notifier framework supports various notifiers to be developed. Currently ceilometer can support three kinds of notifiers which can send alarm notification to a log file or one http destination. But in some applications, users may want alarm notification can be sent through SNMP trap protocol. This spec providers the specification for Ceilometer notifier using SNMP protocol. Problem description =================== There is one usecase: A company already has a monitor system which using SNMP service to receive monitor data and the monitor system can evaluate the alarms according to these data. Now the company deployed an openstack environment and used ceilometer to monitor openstack resources, but they don't want to manage these two kinds of monitor system separately, they need ceilometer has the capability to send alarm notification to the already existed SNMP service. Proposed change =============== A new notifier will be added in ceilometer/alarm/notifier package, the notifier will be named SnmpNotifier by inheriting the AlarmNotifier. The SnmpNotifier will implement the notify method to send notification to snmp service. The snmp python client will be pysnmp which is also used for hardware inspector. Snmp trap function will be used to send alarm notication and the format should be ALARM-MIB which was introduced by rfc3877. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Lan Qi song Primary assignee: lqslan Other contributors: None Ongoing maintainer: lqslan Work Items ---------- * SnmpNotifier * Document on how to configure this notifier Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest tests will be added in ceilometer/tests/alarm/test_alarm.py. These test cases can be invoked at the gate or locally in a dev environment. Documentation Impact ==================== Only additional information will be added to the doc on how to enable and configure this new notifier. References ========== http://pysnmp.sourceforge.net/ https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3877.txt

"""Common code for working with shares """ from __future__ import absolute_import from ceilometer.agent import plugin_base from ceilometer import sample class _Base(plugin_base.PollsterBase): def extract_metadata(self, obj): return dict((k, getattr(obj, k)) for k in self.FIELDS) class ShareSizePollster(_Base): FIELDS = ['id', 'size', 'share_type', 'project_id', 'metadata', 'status'] @property def default_discovery(self): return 'shares' def get_samples(self, manager, cache, resources): for share in resources: yield sample.Sample( name='share.size', type=sample.TYPE_GAUGE, unit='GB', volume=share.size, user_id=share.user_id, project_id=getattr(share, 'project_id'), resource_id=share.id, resource_metadata=self.extract_metadata(share), ) class ShareSnapshotSize(_Base): @property def default_discovery(self): return 'share_snapshots' FIELDS = ['name', 'share_id', 'status', 'description', 'created_at', 'share_proto', 'share_size', 'size' ] def get_samples(self, manager, cache, resources): for snapshot in resources: yield sample.Sample( name='share.snapshot.size', type=sample.TYPE_GAUGE, unit='GB', volume=snapshot.size, user_id=None, project_id=getattr( snapshot, 'project_id'), resource_id=snapshot.id, resource_metadata=self.extract_metadata(snapshot), ) class ShareBackupSize(_Base): @property def default_discovery(self): return 'share_backups' FIELDS = ['name', 'object_count', 'container', 'share_id', 'status', 'description'] def get_samples(self, manager, cache, resources): for backup in resources: yield sample.Sample( name='share.backup.size', type=sample.TYPE_GAUGE, unit='GB', volume=backup.size, user_id=None, project_id=getattr( backup, 'os-backup-project-attr:project_id', None), resource_id=backup.id, resource_metadata=self.extract_metadata(backup), )

commit_message:
Add read performance testing to monasca-api

Using Jmeter to query monasca-api and collect performance numbers related
to database performance and monasca-api interaction.

Change-Id: I315453453b82d90874aefada6f4ac3337512f4e7
story: 2001292
task: 6113
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/44/529144/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: monasca-api performance benchmarking ============= Recommended Configuration ============= Install ======= Install JMeter add JMeter bin to the path: PATH=$PATH:~/.../bin Monasca-query performance test ============================== This test is designed to work with data created from persister-perf performance test but can work with any monasca-api/db configuration. monasca-api will need to have region configured to support test data. JMeter uses monasca-api to query db backend. Load monasca_queryr_test.jmx into jmeter. Setup user defined variables for your environment. Run tests.

commit_message:
Horizon UI message when browser cookies disabled

Used dijango's CSRF_FAILURE_VIEW setting to create
a view indicating the reason the request was rejected.
This information is passed on to the login page so it
can render the error.

Change-Id: I61c7195c9bafb269816fde12b058e19ebc69953c
Closes-Bug: #1412483

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 17.0.0.0b3

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

Change-Id: I5fea16a84c881d0e66b713cdb55c8dcabcb80491
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/80/538680/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- other: - The vars plugin ``override_folder.py`` has been removed. With the move to Ansible 2.4 ["https://review.openstack.org/#/c/522778"] this plugin is no longer required. The functionality this plugin provided has been replaced with the native Ansible inventory plugin.

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I1a4e7050ae4d21af90362f80694e719338b2a5b3

commit_message:
properly escape the release notes text

Escape the list entries as blocks of text so the YAML parser
understands how to process them.

Change-Id: Icd334175270ab1f5f26ea2526fe560165b11559e
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

added_lines: @mock.patch('barbican.model.sync.sync_secret_stores') def test_db_sync_secret_stores_no_args(self, mock_sync_command): manager.CONF.set_override('log_file', 'mock_log_file') self._main_test_helper( ['barbican.cmd.barbican_manage', 'db', 'sync_secret_stores'], func_name=mock_sync_command, sql_url='mockdburl', verbose=False, log_file='mock_log_file') manager.CONF.clear_override('log_file') @mock.patch('barbican.model.sync.sync_secret_stores') def test_db_sync_secret_stores_with_args(self, mock_sync_command): manager.CONF.set_override('log_file', 'mock_log_file') self._main_test_helper( ['barbican.cmd.barbican_manage', 'db', 'sync_secret_stores', '--db-url', 'somewhere', '--verbose', '--log-file', '/tmp/whatevs'], func_name=mock_sync_command, sql_url='somewhere', verbose=True, log_file='/tmp/whatevs') manager.CONF.clear_override('log_file')

subject: use . instead of source.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-29 12:52:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara-dashboard/commit/4b71ea6324863d038f1337445b6b76036751e8e4', 'message': 'use . instead of source.

Code conventions: Use “.” to source script files
When you have to source a script file, for example ,
a credentials file to gain access to user-only or
 admin-only CLI commands, use . instead of source.
See more: https://docs.openstack.org/doc-contrib-guide/

commit_message:
use . instead of source.

Code conventions: Use “.” to source script files
When you have to source a script file, for example ,
a credentials file to gain access to user-only or
 admin-only CLI commands, use . instead of source.
See more:
http://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/writing-style/code-conventions

Change-Id: Ic4fd2da622f21e51f813e711cdedb7d1998592fd

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I34e200375e555d5ba86a9f6a6209132ddd2485a6

commit_message:
Remove infracloud-chocolate from nodepool

Because we've lost access to infracloud-chocolate controller, we
cannot properly remove it from nodepool.  As such, remove
configuration from nodepool and grafana.

It was a fun run while it lasted!

Change-Id: I589732d76761275b88dd153ff9e55a78d35483eb
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
python-blazarclient 1.0.1

This should correct the broken 1.0.0 release. The diff-start instruction
applies to the release announcement email to ensure all of the 1.0.0
changes are included there.

Change-Id: Idf2329fa0766ae99426649fd33a21870ccddf95b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Release django-openstack-auth 4.0.0 for project retirement

It was suggested to create a new major version of django-openstack-auth
as a transitional package to stop providing any module itself.
Queens release of horizon is planned to depend on the new DOA release.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-January/126431.html

While django-openstack-auth queens deliverable file was removed
in commit 61d637ad16, considering the above suggestion, it sounds better
to release django-openstack-auth 4.0.0 as queens deliverable.

Note that stable/queens branch is not needed due to the project retirement.

Change-Id: Ib0679150a8d70c328496c7104636983641b8c3e0

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I49df89c5fcd7f119cdbd0ffd977ca124a2e51cda

commit_message:
introduce a ci team structure policy

The CI team has decided to update the way we
are working with each other and outside teams.
This policy doc explains the new policy and why
it is needed.

Change-Id: I96dbab8402d933ccb4d1e7158b62bc88dd5b8abc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/80/509280/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CI Team Structure ================= Problem Description ------------------- The soft analysis over the past one to two years is that landing major new features and function in CI is difficult while being interrupted by a constant stream of issues. Each individual is siloed in their own work, feature or section of the production chain and there is very little time for thoughtful peer review and collaborative development. Policy ------ Goals ^^^^^ * Increase developer focus, decrease distractions, interruptions, and time slicing. * Encourage collaborative team development. * Better and faster code reviews Team Structure ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * The Ruck * The Rover * The Sprint Team The Ruck ^^^^^^^^ One person per week will be on the front lines reporting failures found in CI. The Ruck & Rover switch roles in the second week of the sprint. * Primary focus is to watch CI, report bugs, improve debug documentation. * Does not participate in the sprint * Attends the OpenStack Program call * Responds to pings on #oooq / #tripleo regarding CI * Reviews and improves documentation * Attends the release delivery meetings * Current release (mandatory) * Previous release (mandatory) * Attends meetings for the group where possible * Subscribes to tripleo-ci-ruck at redhat (link) The Rover ^^^^^^^^^ The primary backup for the Ruck. The Ruck should be catching all the issues in CI and passing the issues to the Rover for more in depth analysis or resolution of the bug. * Back up for the Ruck * Workload is driven from the tripleo-quickstart bug queue, the Rover is not monitoring CI * A secondary input for work is identified technical debt defined in the Trello board. * Attends the sprint meetings, but is not responsible for any sprint work. * Helps to triage incoming gerrit reviews along with the TC. * Responds to pings on irc #oooq / #tripleo * If the Ruck is overwhelmed with any of the their responsibilities the Rover is the primary backup. The Sprint Team ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The team is defined at the beginning of the sprint based on availability. Members on the team should be as focused on the sprint epic as possible. A member of team should spend 80% of their time on sprint goals and 20% on any other duties like code review or incoming high priority bugs that the Rover can not manage alone. * hand off interruptions to the Ruck and Rover as much as possible * focus as a team on the sprint epic * collaborate with other members of the sprint team * seek out peer review regarding sprint work * keep the Trello board updated daily * One can point to Trello cards in stand up meetings for status Sprint Structure ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The goal of the sprint is to define a narrow and focused feature called an epic to work on in a collaborative way. Work not completed in the sprint will be added to the technical debt column of Trello. **Note:** Each sprint needs a clear definition of done that is documented in the epic used for the sprint. Sprint Start ( Day 1 ) - 4 hours ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * Sprints are two weeks in length * A planning meeting is attended by the entire team including the Ruck and Rover * Review PTO * Assign Ruck and Rover positions * Review any meetings that need to be covered by the Ruck/Rover * Trello Board triage * Bug triage * The PM and UA will present a number of options for the sprint epic * Discuss the epic, lightly breaking each one down (30 minutes) * Vote on an epic * Break down the sprint epic into cards * Review each card * Each card must have a clear definition of done * As a group include as much detail in the card as to provide enough information for an engineer with little to no background with the task. Sprint End ( Day 10 ) - 4 hours ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * Retrospective ( 30 min ) * Document any technical debt left over from the sprint * Gerrit Review meeting ( 30 min ) * Ruck / Rover hand off ( 15 min ) * TripleO Community CI meeting ( 30 - 60 min ) * Office hours on irc ( 60 min ) Scrum meetings ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * Planning meeting, video conference ( 4 hours ) * Spring End, video and irc #oooq on freenode ( 4 hours ) * 2 live video conference meetings per week * sprint stand up ( 30 min ) * Other days, post status to etherpad * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-ci-squad-scrum Leaders ------- The team catalyst ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * organize and plan sprint meetings * status emails The user advocate ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * organize and prioritize the Trello board for the sprint planning * monitor the board during hte sprint. * ensure the right work is being done. Alternatives & History ---------------------- In the past the CI team has worked as individuals or by pairing up for distinct parts of the CI system and for certain features. Neither has been overwhelmingly successful for delivering features on a regular cadence. Implementation -------------- Primary author: Wes Hayutin weshayutin at gmail Other contributors: * Ronelle Landy rlandy at redhat * Arx Cruz acruz at redhat * Sagi Shnaidman at redhat Milestones ---------- This document is likely to evolve from the feedback discussed in sprint retrospectives. An in depth retrospective should be done at the end of each upstream cycle. References ---------- Trello ^^^^^^ A Trello board will be used to organize work. The team is expected to keep the board and their cards updated on a daily basis. * https://trello.com/b/U1ITy0cu/tripleo-ci-squad Dashboards ^^^^^^^^^^ A number of dashboards are used to monitor the CI * http://cistatus.tripleo.org/ * https://dashboards.rdoproject.org/rdo-dev * http://zuul-status.tripleo.org/ Team Notes ^^^^^^^^^^ * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-ci-squad-meeting Bug Queue ^^^^^^^^^ * http://tinyurl.com/yag6y9ne Revision History ---------------- .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - October 03 2017 .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

subject: WIP: Add regression test wrinkle for rebuilding twice with invalid image
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-29 15:52:46.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/functional/test_servers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/860c8961234b47d2fb07d84ecf82bf4888b43203', 'message': "WIP: Add regression test wrinkle for rebuilding twice with invalid image

This shows that if we fail to rebuild with an invalid image, we are
able to rebuild a second time with the same image and it's allowed.
This is due to a bug where the API saves the new image ref on the
instance and doesn't roll it back when the scheduling failure occurs,
so that the subsequent attempt with the invalid image is allowed because
the API sees that the image isn't changing (even though the backing
image on the instance never changed) and the scheduler is bypassed.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1539703

Change-Id: Ibc4a2a3c885c23c74edfd6435076675317068868
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Add regression test wrinkle for rebuilding twice with invalid image

This shows that if we fail to rebuild with an invalid image, we are
able to rebuild a second time with the same image and it's allowed.
This is due to a bug where the API saves the new image ref on the
instance and doesn't roll it back when the scheduling failure occurs,
so that the subsequent attempt with the invalid image is allowed because
the API sees that the image isn't changing (even though the backing
image on the instance never changed) and the scheduler is bypassed.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1539703

Change-Id: Ibc4a2a3c885c23c74edfd6435076675317068868
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/55/538955/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Rebuild it again with the same bad image to make sure it's rejected # again. # FIXME(mriedem): Due to bug 1539703 the first rebuild failure changed # the instance.image_ref to the bad image, and on the second attempt # the API thinks the image isn't changing, so it bypasses the # scheduler. This should fail once the bug is fixed. # self.assertRaises( # client.OpenStackApiException, self.api.api_post, # '/servers/%s/action' % server['id'], rebuild_req_body) self.api.api_post('/servers/%s/action' % server['id'], rebuild_req_body) self._wait_for_state_change(self.api, server, 'ACTIVE')

commit_message:
Support soft-anti-affinity policy for nodes

Currently, there is no guarantee to make sure all nodes of one cluster are
created on different compute hosts. So it would be nice if we can create
a server group and set it with anti-affinity policy to get a better HA
for cluster. This patch is proposing to create a server group for master
and minion nodes with soft-anti-affinity policy by default.

Closes-Bug: #1737802

Change-Id: Icc7a73ef55296a58bf00719ca4d1cdcc304fab86

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Iac1150ec8dc2529339bc65e552b5ef15b92c438d

commit_message:
Adds Workflow to List Available Roles

This patch adds a workflow to list available roles for a given
deployment plan by reading the roles directory in the plan's
swift container and returning a json structure of role yaml
files present.

Implements: blueprint tripleo-common-list-available-roles-action

Change-Id: I23087bd38c3730c9f24e03e4d7c54688ae912b08
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/32/509832/40 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ListAvailableRolesAction(base.TripleOAction): """Returns a deployment plan's roles available to be used for deployment Parses /roles directory of a given container and returns the names of all available roles. :param container: name of the Swift container / plan name :return: list of roles in the container's deployment plan """ def __init__(self, container=constants.DEFAULT_CONTAINER_NAME): super(ListAvailableRolesAction, self).__init__() self.container = container def run(self, context): try: swift = self.get_object_client(context) roles_data = [swift.get_object(self.container, item['name'])[1] for item in swift.get_container(self.container)[1] if item['name'].startswith("roles/") and item['name'].endswith(".yaml")] except Exception as err: err_msg = ("Error retrieving roles data from deployment plan: %s" % err) LOG.exception(err_msg) return actions.Result(error=err_msg) return roles_data

subject: Pass blacklisted_{ip_addresses,hostnames} to major_upgrade_steps
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-25 16:52:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/8ae581d2806e326ba2a7d01b4ea0c6030baea6e9', 'message': 'Pass blacklisted_{ip_addresses,hostnames} to major_upgrade_steps

Durig upgrade PostDeploySteps is mapped into major_upgrade_steps
which was missing blacklisted_{ip_addresses,hostnames} previously
added only into deploy-steps.

Change-Id: Ifdcdad63e430972f7254f0c40e021b00333fdf56
Closes-Bug: 1745379

commit_message:
Pass blacklisted_{ip_addresses,hostnames} to major_upgrade_steps

Durig upgrade PostDeploySteps is mapped into major_upgrade_steps

commit_message:
Ensure to mark exception message as tranlation strings

- in exception.py Class ServiceCatalogException
  an exception message is untranslated,
- in k2k.oy Class K2KAuthPlugin def get_plugin
  an exception message is untranslated.

Change-Id: I7d09f625cc3e074bc5a40478668c7b382613da2f
Signed-off-by: peiy <peiy@rc.inesa.com>

commit_message:
Load undercloud DB password to a mistral environment

This patch adds a new variable to the mistral
environment 'tripleo.undercloud-config' allowing
to retrieve the root password for the MySQL
databases. Now this variable can be accessed from any
Mistral workflow.
Also, this patch adds the ability of checking if
the variables are not loaded properly due to
an upgrade, in that case we update the Mistral
environment to have all the variables in place.

Change-Id: I822c3d96b5805909656d8e92e963b851f3bd77de
(cherry picked from commit be3bd48214e6719db9bd364f020ea5b652b9a536)
Related-Bug: 1742191

Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
use openstack command instead of nova command

In function 'get_instance_ip', 'nova' client command is used to get
instance information in order to retrive IP address of the instance.

There is no need to use the nova command, since 'openstack' client
already supports such basic operation.

Moreover, 'openstack' client has an option to get value of specified
column. That brings more accurate way of retriving IP address.

This patch replaces nova command in 'get_instance_ip' by 'openstack'
command. Note, this nova command is the only one in devstack tree.

Change-Id: Iee0b81a994a4da5b3f4572c2e8eb30514cd43f89
Signed-off-by: Ryota MIBU <r-mibu@cq.jp.nec.com>

subject: Future of classic drivers: update the migration proposal
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-22 10:40:12.000000000', 'files': ['specs/approved/classic-drivers-future.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/commit/08b5820be460dd0d8de12126eeb6c04dcc6a0eed', 'message': 'Future of classic drivers: update the migration proposal

As I started working on the migration implementation, it became
apparent that the current proposal is not the best. This patch
makes the following changes:

1. Do not calculate migration per node, but rather per driver. Doing
   it per node is not required for the current classic drivers.
   It complicates the database code and makes it potentially less
   efficient, because we need to fetch and update every node
   separately.

2. Return hardware type and interfaces separately from to_hardware_types.
   Also return interfaces without _interface suffix. This simplifies
   additional checks in the migration code.

3. Add support for options in migrations, and add an option to reset
   unsupported interfaces to no-<interface>. This is needed to make
   this migration more usable. For example, for ``pxe_ipmitool``
   to be migrated under the current proposal, a deployment must have
   ``agent`` RAID and ``shellinabox`` console enabled, even if it
   does not use and/or does not support them. The new options will
   allow such deployments to have unsupported interfaces reset.

Change-Id: I194be98bdd1f307ce6b9054a0037788f81cb0d23
Related-Bug: #1690185
'}]
commit_message:
Future of classic drivers: update the migration proposal

As I started working on the migration implementation, it became
apparent that the current proposal is not the best. This patch
makes the following changes:

1. Do not calculate migration per node, but rather per driver. Doing
   it per node is not required for the current classic drivers.
   It complicates the database code and makes it potentially less
   efficient, because we need to fetch and update every node
   separately.

2. Return hardware type and interfaces separately from to_hardware_types.
   Also return interfaces without _interface suffix. This simplifies
   additional checks in the migration code.

3. Add support for options in migrations, and add an option to reset
   unsupported interfaces to no-<interface>. This is needed to make
   this migration more usable. For example, for ``pxe_ipmitool``
   to be migrated under the current proposal, a deployment must have
   ``agent`` RAID and ``shellinabox`` console enabled, even if it
   does not use and/or does not support them. The new options will
   allow such deployments to have unsupported interfaces reset.

Change-Id: I194be98bdd1f307ce6b9054a0037788f81cb0d23
Related-Bug: #1690185
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/98/536298/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def to_hardware_type(cls): :returns: a tuple with two items: * new driver field - the target hardware type * dictionary containing interfaces to update, e.g. {'deploy': 'iscsi', 'power': 'ipmitool'} def to_hardware_type(cls): return 'ipmi', {'boot': 'pxe', 'deploy': 'direct', 'inspect': inspect_interface, 'management': 'ipmitool', 'power': 'ipmitool', 'raid': 'agent'} * Update the ``online_data_migrations`` to accept options for migrations in the form of ``--option <MIGRATION NAME><KEY>=<VALUE>``. They will be passed as keyword arguments to the migration matching the provided name. * Update the ``online_data_migrations`` command with a new migration ``migrate_to_harware_types``. It will accept one option ``reset_unsupported_interfaces``, which is a boolean value with the default of ``False``. The migration will do the following: #. For each classic driver: Missing interfaces, other than ``boot``, ``deploy``, ``management`` and ``power``, are defaulted to their no-op implementations (``no-***``). We consider ``boot``, ``deploy``, ``management`` and ``power`` mandatory, as they do not have a no-op implementation. #. If the hardware type is not in ``enabled_hardware_types``, issue a and skip all nodes with this classic driver. #. If any interface is not enabled (not in ``enabled_***_interfaces``): #. if this interface is one of ``boot``, ``deploy``, ``management`` or ``power``, or if ``reset_unsupported_interfaces`` is ``False``, issue a warning and skip the nodes. #. otherwise try again with resetting the interface to its no-op implementation (``no-***``). .. note:: Due to idempotency of the migrations, operators will be able to re-run this command after fixing the warnings to update the skipped nodes.
deleted_lines: def to_hardware_type(cls, node): :param cls: the driver class :param node: node record from the database :returns: dictionary containing node fields to update: ``driver`` and all interface fields (except for ``network`` and ``storage`` which have always been dynamic, even for nodes with a classic driver). def to_hardware_type(cls, node): return {'driver': 'ipmi', 'boot_interface': 'pxe', 'console_interface': 'no-console', 'deploy_interface': 'direct', 'inspect_interface': inspect_interface, 'management_interface': 'ipmitool', 'power_interface': 'ipmitool', 'raid_interface': 'agent', 'vendor_interface': 'no-vendor'} * Update the ``online_data_migration`` command with a new migration: #. For each node using a classic driver: #. If the hardware type or any interface is not in the enabled list (``enabled_hardware_types`` or ``enabled_***_interfaces``), issue a warning and skip the node. Due to idempotency of the migrations, operators will be able to re-run this command after fixing the warnings to update the skipped nodes.

commit_message:
Running new workflow based on an existing execution.

This change would allow an operator to start a new workflow execution
based on an existing one, it would also recall all parameters needed
to start the workflow.

Implements blueprint: mistral-run-workflow-from-execution
Change-Id: Iec3d9f3a71a98952860b972acd09ce80e0a849ff
